question: Based on the provided evidence, answer the following question: A 19-year-old man in a 3-month relationship with a woman experiences frequent sexual fantasies about male coworkers. He lives in a conservative community and does not know any openly gay men. Two days ago, he joined a local group considered by many organizations to be a hate group. Together with the other members, he attacked a gay couple on their way home from dinner. What psychological defense mechanisms is he demonstrating?. If there are multiple answers, separate them with commas. In your explanation, point out what is correct and incorrect in the evidence.

content.source_1: A 19-year-old man in a 3-month relationship with a woman reports frequent sexual fantasies about male coworkers while residing in a conservative community where he does not know any openly gay men; two days prior to presentation, he joined a local group considered by many organizations to be a hate group and, together with other members, attacked a gay couple on their way home from dinner. From a psychodynamic standpoint, the juxtaposition of persistent same-sex fantasies with overtly hostile, homophobic behavior is most parsimoniously interpreted as defensive overcompensation via reaction formation, wherein unacceptable sexual desires are warded off by adopting and enacting attitudes diametrically opposed to those desires. Concurrently, the aggressive targeting of a gay couple suggests projection, namely the attribution of one’s own disavowed impulses to external others who then become the focus of condemnation and attack. In this context, the convergence of concealed homosexual ideation, a sociocultural milieu discouraging disclosure, and the rapid escalation to anti-gay violence is consistent with a dual defensive pattern dominated by reaction formation and projection. Reaction Formation, Projection.
content.source_2: A 19-year-old man in a 3-month heterosexual relationship who experiences frequent sexual fantasies about male coworkers, lives in a conservative community without knowing any openly gay men, and who, two days ago, joined a local group considered by many organizations to be a hate group and participated with other members in attacking a gay couple on their way home from dinner, presents a defense-mechanism profile best resolved through a structured differential. Denial and repression are less likely given the evident presence of recurring same-sex fantasies; sublimation is inconsistent with channeling into prosocial outlets; and displacement is improbable because the chosen targets directly embody the content of the unacceptable impulses rather than serving as neutral substitutes. By contrast, projection is suggested by the attribution of unaccepted same-sex desires to external individuals (the gay couple), thereby legitimizing hostility toward them, while reaction formation is supported by the adoption of overtly anti-gay attitudes and behaviors that invert the individual’s underlying desires, amplified by alignment with a hate group. Taken together, the behavioral and contextual data favor a primacy of projection in tandem with reaction formation. Projection, Reaction Formation.
content.source_3: A 19-year-old man in a 3-month relationship with a woman, residing in a conservative community and knowing no openly gay men, reports frequent sexual fantasies about male coworkers; two days earlier he joined a local group considered by many organizations to be a hate group and, acting with its members, attacked a gay couple on their way home from dinner. This pattern is consistent with internalized conflict regarding sexual orientation manifesting through two complementary defense mechanisms: projection, wherein unacceptable same-sex desires are externalized and ascribed to others who are then targeted, and reaction formation, in which the subject overadopts antithetical attitudes and conduct—here, marked homophobic hostility and group-affiliated violence—to counteract and conceal disavowed impulses. The rapid transition from concealed desire to organized, oppositional behavior within a hostile sociocultural context supports a conjoint operation of these mechanisms in driving the observed aggression. Projection and Reaction Formation.
